divs: sighting detailsthe incident occurred in late 1969 or early 1970. i was in my late teens, and my family were at the time living in santurce, puerto rico, a suburb of san juan. the building we lived in was seven stories tall, and it was my habit to go up and sit alone on the top of the elevator stack to watch the sunset. the building was about half a block away from the ocean, on the north coast of the island. the evening was mild, with very few clouds, and those far off to the west. the sea wind had dropped, as it does at sunset, and the down-slope land breeze had not yet started for the night, so the air was fairly still. i was facing west, but had leaned back to watch the stars start to appear as the light faded. at this point, i saw a strong red light above me, moving very fast, from approximately straight overhead, in an arc to the north\northwest out towards the ocean. my first thought was that it was a meteorite. the light reached a point perhaps 10 to 15 degrees above the horizon, and stopped suddenly, with no slowing. when it stopped, i could see that it was a large red light, with a much smaller, but very intense white light slightly to the left of it. it was sufficiently far away that i could not make out any details. (if i had held a quarter out at arm���s length, it would have covered both lights.) the lights stayed in one place for perhaps 2 to 3 seconds, then moved slowly, horizontally, and at almost a right angle to their previous path, toward the northeast, out over the ocean. the red light was definitely in front of the intense, smaller white one, and there was a slight distance between them, but it seemed to me that both lights were on the same object. after another 12 to 15 seconds, both lights suddenly went out, and i saw no more of them, nor was there anything else in the vicinity of that sort. they did not simply dwindle into the distance; they went out while they were still quite visible in the darkness over the ocean. i did not hear any sounds which appeared to be connected to the lights. after a few minutes, i went down from the roof of the building, as i was already somewhat later than usual. i told my mother about this at the time; she said that i must have seen "some kind of military aircraft," which i doubted, but i did not mention it to anyone else, or try to report it. there were indeed two large military bases within 40 miles of my location, but i had frequently seen and heard assorted military aircraft, none of which had behaved in that way. shortly after this incident, security concerns caused the owners of the building to lock the roof, so i was no longer able to watch the evenings from there, and within a year i had moved away from the area. i have seldom mentioned this to anyone, and have never attempted to report it to any other organization.
